citations: William B. McGregor,Linguistics: An Introduction, 2nd ed. (London and New York: Bloomsbury, 2015), 428; Emanuel Hertz,The Hidden Lincoln(New York: Blue Ribbon Books, 1940), 400.

footnotes.text:
1This tale strings together “spoonerisms,” a type of wordplay in which the author transposes
                  the first letter in two or more words for humorous effect. Spoonerisms and other forms
                  of wordplay were popular in the early 19th century. Although written inAbraham Lincoln’s handwriting, it is unclear whether the text originated with Lincoln. Jesse Weik,
                  one of Lincoln’s early biographers, stated that the document had been given by Lincoln
                  to a Springfield court official. Editors have been unable to determine a more specific
                  date for the document.William B. McGregor,Linguistics: An Introduction, 2nd ed. (London and New York: Bloomsbury, 2015), 428; Emanuel Hertz,The Hidden Lincoln(New York: Blue Ribbon Books, 1940), 400.
